39427834.review:
A Raven Monologue is a free five-minute semi-interactive film. The only real controls are clicking forward and back to advance the story, like moving to the next panel of a comic. (Even this gets played with a bit partway through, though.) As you click through, a wordless abstract story unfolds, accompanied by charming artwork and a beautiful if somewhat sad song.

It is artsy as heck and open to interpretation (I personally see it as [spoiler]a tale about loneliness; the raven yearns for company and either conjures up imaginary townsfolk or gets lost in memories about now-departed ones, only to slink home alongside his sad piles of rocks as reality ensues,[/spoiler] but who knows?) but it's pretty and well made.

Recommended, partly because it's such a low barrier of entry.  It's short, easy, and free, so why not, but there's also DLC pack with wallpapers and stuff if you want to toss a few dollars the developers' way to thank them for this. Meanwhile, I'll be here for hugs if anyone needs them.

"A Raven Monologue" is the perfect definition of why video games ARE art. Beautiful music from the start, forces you into an emotional and yet mysterious story. Following a Raven and his interaction with everyone in his small town, piece by piece he adds treasures to his cage until the plot takes a turn and leads Raven Man back in the litural opposite direction, where he eventually finds that all his friends are now gone. 

Very much recommend and after all, it's FREE! 

Take a watch of my video or play it for yourself. Either way, CONGRATS to the creators of an astounding game!

“乌鸦独白”（Raven Monologue）是一个简短的实验性的沉默故事，讲述了一只不会叫的乌鸦，以及他与镇上人民的关系。

这个实验是Mojiken Studio的内部升级程序＃MojikenCamp2的一部分，用于试验如何讲述故事或使用受限制的互动艺术作品来交流经验。

[h1]特征[/h1]
[list]
    [*]无声的乌鸦
    [*]虚构的人
    [*]手绘艺术
    [*]一个你可以无限解释的故事
    [*]Christabel Annora的音乐 
[/list]

39382189.review:
在玩了好几次，仔细听了听歌词，再结合查了一些资料后，终于有了属于自己的对这个故事的解释。“关于这个故事的解释”给了我一些启迪与启示。短诗的形式，我觉得表达了作者的创作意图：“ about a raven that does not know how to croak and his relationship with the people in the town.”虽然说的是一只乌鸦，但何尝又不是人们自己呢？不会表达的人是不是就是故事里的“silent raven”呢？
不会说话的乌鸦，想去亲近别人，却不懂如何去爱，去表达。只能接受，索要他爱的人的纪念品，永远保存下来。但是，人们渐渐从他视野中远去，孤独的乌鸦如何去表达他的爱呢？只是going，going。无数次的徘徊无数次的经过曾经的道路，用石头代替他爱的人们来重复一次又一次的邂逅，一次又一次的感受孤独与悲伤……
笔者一直坚信，这类游戏的物品必定存在属于他自己的意象，花代表如花似玉少女，茂盛的绿叶代表着热情健康的大叔，树枝代表着硬朗却瘦小的老奶奶，风车代表着自由美好的儿童。但为什么游戏的图标是风车却不是Mr.Raven呢？是象征着不断轮回的日子？是对唯一向自己伸出手递过风车的小女孩的爱，还是？？？
Mr.Raven一直提着鸟笼徘徊，鸟笼和里面的石头又代表着什么？我想，大概那是他自己和他自己的家。或许整个故事的一切都只是笼子里乌鸦的幻想，也或许是作者对Mr.Raven生活状态的映射，还或许是Mr.Raven对曾经的自己的纪念，更或许是希望自己，能一直和花、树叶、树枝、风车在一起……
正如Feature所说的那样“A story that you can interpret without limit”不同的人会对其有不同的看法，希望每个人不要拘泥于评论的看法，看不懂就自己去重复看，去听歌词，去带入角色，去看Mr.Raven的一举一动。
得到属于自己的看法，是对这个故事，这个游戏最大的赞美与尊重。

39376673.review:
Well. This is definitely art. It's clearly just an experiment, but I've always found great interest in things as non conventional as this. It's absolutely not a taste that everyone can enjoy, but then again, what is? Even long after it was over, for such a short experience, it left quite an impact in me. That's not something that can be said about a lot of things. 

There's much to be improved in terms of...a few things. Like the music's correlation with the "Interactivity", if you can call going forward and back between images interactivity, and while it's a clever idea that does work, it does need a little more effort than this, even for something simple. There really is nothing else to be said about it. But now that the critical aspect is over...

The art style is really lovely. It reminds me of the kinds of things I would read as a little kid, and the books my grandfather would give my sister, too. And the music shattered my soul. Thanks.

Farewell.

39353413.review:
[h1]The f*ck did I just experience?![/h1]

As stated on its store page, [i]A Raven Monologue[/i] is an experimental game to tell a narrative story in less than 5 minutes.    Going forward, I was confused.  Going backward, I guess I had an idea of what was going on.  In the end, though, I'm only left confused.

In my interpretation, [spoiler]the raven is a plague doctor and he accepts gifts of various people he treated.  However, when going back, he's revisited his patients to only find stones (gravestones) of where they were, meaning that they ultimately succumbed to the bubonic plague, regardless of whether he treated them or not.[/spoiler].  But that's just my interpretation.

The visuals look good and the song sounds great.  But I didn't care for the story, which only weirded me out.  Don't get me wrong.  I really enjoyed what went into this project, but in all honesty, I cannot recommend this game simply because I didn't enjoy it.  You may find yourself as weirded out as I was by the narrative.  On the plus side, it is short, looks good, and sounds good.

4/10  A short wordless narrative that only supplied an eerie, empty feeling rather than a sense of satisfaction.

看了很多评测，说一下仅仅个人对故事的理解，包含严重剧透，想玩的千万别看：
[spoiler] 一切的关键在于颜色。一开始乌鸦先生的世界里除了黑白关键还有蓝色。乌鸦先生遇到的每个人都给了世界新的颜色：采花的妹子给了花，世界便有了红色；桥上的大叔给了叶，世界便有了绿色；杵拐的老人给了木，世界便有了棕色。直到乌鸦先生在树林中遇到了荡秋千的小女孩，她给了风车——蓝色的，但这是世界中已有的颜色。这一不协调触发了真空相变。乌鸦先生再看时，风车只是对石头的幻想，小女孩也是，蓝色便是幻想的无处可依，世界一直都没有蓝色。再往回走时，杵拐的老人也是对石头的幻想，世界也一直没有棕色；桥上的大叔也是对石头的幻想，世界也一直没有绿色；采花的妹子也是对石头的幻想，世界也一直没有红色。在只有黑白的世界中乌鸦先生孓然一人，打开放着花、叶、木的鸟笼，那些也只是幻想，随风消散了，只剩下孤独沉默的石头。

直到不知过了多久，在静止与沉默世界中的渴望又压倒了现实而产生幻想，一切又重新来过。蓝色是幻想的开始、破缺与结束。一切只是"monologue"，只是独白。

而一切又因为“About This Game”，”关于这款游戏“下的那首诗而产生希望：
[quote=呆罗]
「亲爱的乌鸦先生，」
「你还在到处流浪吗？」
「在静止与沉默的世界中制造色彩」
「却不知我正孑然一身，默默等待」

「亲爱的乌鸦先生，」
「当你在附近时，你会介意停下脚步吗？」
「只需一个问候，只需片刻的停留」
「让我在别离之前享受回忆」

「亲爱的乌鸦先生，」
「让我们牵手回家吧！」
「去往没有现实桎梏的地方」
「即使脱离了常识，也将于此守候着彼此」
[/quote]
在这封闭的黑白世界之外似乎有一个“她”在等待，等待着乌鸦先生从黑白世界中解放自己，一起过上幸福的生活。[i] P.S. 这诗简直就像在写“海伯利安四部曲”被封在猫箱中的安迪密恩和等待他的伊妮娅。[/i][/spoiler]

39334966.review:
[h1]无声而悲凉的风，带走了一切[/h1]
这是一曲孤独的独白，无需言语。
这是属于[b]乌鸦先生的独白[/b]。

故事所展开的小镇：
[list]
[*]有鲜活的[b]红色[/b]
[*]有稳重的[b]棕色[/b]
[*]有生命的[b]绿色[/b]
[*]有可爱的[b]蓝色[/b]

[*]有阴霾的[b]灰色[/b]
[/list]

他们的色彩带来了一切，却最终变成一片[b]寂静的灰色[/b]。

[b]10/10[/b]

以下是个人分析（可能存在剧透）：
[spoiler]
乌鸦先生暗指驱除瘟疫的医生。
最开始笼中只有一块石头，那便是被囚禁的瘟疫。
后来，医生来到小镇帮助他们治疗瘟疫。
人心是善良的，善良的人们与乌鸦先生在言语之间逐渐让他开始喜欢上这座小镇。
瘟疫是无情的，当乌鸦先生回过头来——一切都已经失去了色彩，化为一片寂静。
那是恐怖的寂静；无情的寂静。
乌鸦先生想要触碰那最后一丝色彩，却又在指尖触碰的瞬间凋零。
他回到了起点，开始的地方。
如果要说有什么不一样的，可能那就是他藏在心里的悲伤吧。
[/spoiler]

这可能也是一个孤独的人的独白吧。毕竟给予石头再多生命也不能让他活过来。

This contains spoilers and my interpretation.
[spoiler]
Everyone in the story has their item. Raven has stone in the cage too. Everyone except him talks about their thing. And when they talk the raven collects what they tell him and puts it in cage so he can use these to describe the world around him -that's why it goes more colorful with every item. He also uses those words collected to talk with people. He eventually meets the girl with a pinwheel. But this time its not the same. He gets from her a physical thing. The girl isn't talking. At this moment girl is showing him what are really people, their things, and their words. Girl turns into stone. And so does her thing in hands of the raven. When he's going back he can only see the stones and the things layed near to them. Those are people who have nothing new to say. And what they are to you when you heard them already and you hear the same thing over an over. They are only made of what they carry. When you take it away, there is nothing left. Which you do by just hearing them out and remembering it. He gets back home. He let's all the thoughts go. And he goes again. And even tho people are stones. He still gets all these things that before. Because those people just always were stones. When he get's to the blue girl again pinwheel is still there. When raven picks it up it turns into stone for him same as before. And the story repeats. Like a spinning pinwheel.
[/spoiler]

「亲爱的乌鸦先生，」
「你还在到处流浪吗？」

「却不知我正孑然一身，默默等待」

[h1]《乌鸦独白》，一部含着淡淡忧伤的简短连环画
用一首歌的时间，品味一段孤单者的心酸故事[/h1]

[spoiler]故事中「乌鸦先生」黑袍、长鸟嘴的形象很像是中世纪欧洲黑死病爆发时期疫医的装扮，我们可以推测，这个故事实际上讲的是「乌鸦先生」作为一名医生来到疫情爆发的小镇，他遇见了可爱的送花姑娘，桥上的壮年大叔，颤巍巍的拄拐婆婆，还有森林里陪他渡过一段美好时光的风车少女。[/spoiler]

[spoiler]但是，他什么都做不了。他拼尽了全力，想要阻止死神在小镇上挥舞镰刀……可最终却全是徒劳。大家……都死了。[/spoiler]

[spoiler]「乌鸦先生」孤独地走在死寂的小镇，周围的世界全部陷入了灰色。
他独自一人走来，却还是独自一人离开。
有人欢迎，却没有人欢送。[/spoiler]

[spoiler]这，便是他的独白。[/spoiler]

BGM为[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RGk6zOuD6wY][u]Selfishness[/u][/url]。
镇上新搬来一位乌鸦先生，但他从不出门，镇上的人都对他充满好奇。
终于有一天，一个女孩敲开了他的房门。
“你好呀乌鸦先生，这是我刚采的花枝，请收下吧”
“应该能结出许多花儿”，看着小女孩手中的花，乌鸦先生想到。
于是他收下了这束花枝。
出去走一走看一看吧，乌鸦先生对自己说。
走了不远，乌鸦先生看到一个大叔，扛着一捆灌木。
“远来的客人哟，请收下这枝灌木吧”
“应该能生出许多叶子吧”，乌鸦先生想。
于是他收下了这枝灌木。
这里的人可真热情，乌鸦先生脚步不由得轻快起来。
乌鸦先生遇见了一位老妇人。
“远道而来的客人啊，你在寻找什么，需要帮助吗？”
乌鸦先生打量了一下老人，目光定格在她的拐杖上。
“也许能长出许多树枝呢”，乌鸦先生想。
“这一节送给你吧”老妇人似乎看出了他的想法。
不知走了多久，乌鸦先生来到一片树林中。
林中有个秋千，一个小女孩坐在上面，手里握着一个纸风车。
“早上好啊先生”女孩很热情。
乌鸦先生走上前，他伸了伸手，示意女孩他想要这个纸风车。
处于友好，女孩递出了玩具。

纸风车转动间，不知过了多久。

乌鸦先生又一次在森林中遇到女孩，女孩荡着秋千，只是对他礼貌地笑笑。
乌鸦先生决定回家，他又遇到了老妇人，老妇人从他身边走过。
“这里的人都变了吗”沮丧的乌鸦先生继续往回走。
他又在桥上遇见了大叔，大叔和上次一样扛着一捆灌木，匆匆擦肩而过。
前方就是家了，他又看到了邻居女孩。
乌鸦先生在期待着什么，但女孩仍在专心地筛拣花枝。
进了屋，放下鸟笼，笼中没有鲜花，没有灌木，也没有茂密的枝杈。
乌鸦先生又一次陷入沮丧之中。

日复一日，乌鸦先生依然不知道怎么和镇上的人相处。
每次出门，看着一个个熟悉又陌生的面孔，乌鸦先生多希望回到刚开始的那一天。
但乌鸦先生不知道，心如磐石，如何长出枝杈、生出叶子、结出鲜花呢？
以自我为中心，又怎么融入一个集体呢？

39293860.review:
Beautiful artstyle and soundtrack, which is only a single song that will loop if you keep the story open long enough. You have to think about what's going and really take the time to notice the changes to color in the background to get a better understanding of the story. Although the story is left rather open-ended and up to interpretation, I think. I'm still not 100% sure what A Raven Monologue was about beyond the listing description and specualtions made by other people's reviews and comments, but it's certainly something that will leave you contemplating what you saw.


Truthfully, if this had cost money, I'd have given it a thumbs down, but since it's free whether you like it or not there's no risk of losing money over this. I'm not really sure how I feel about A Raven Monologue other than each individual aspect to the story is lovely. Overall though? I'm fairly neutral, but maybe that'll change over time if I even remember this story later on. Kind of forgettable to me, but a visually appealing story nonetheless. Not worthy of a "not recommended", but I can't say I'd strongly recommend this either.

Be sure to go backwards once you can no longer progress. It's incredibly short and only takes about 10 minutes to get through if you take your time to look around with each scene.

39275967.review:
A short yet colorful game with Victorianesque style aesthetics, a great melodic song, and dare I say it, an underlying Nietzschean worldview. 

[spoiler]This short game is rich in Nietzschean symbolism and ideals and can be considered a good example of Nietzsche's messages. In the beginning of game we are set in a house with a raven sitting next to a rock inside a cage which can be interpreted as his nihlistic tendencies and outlook on the world. As a girl knocks on the door and presents him with a single flower we are thrusted into a well-drawn, and atmospheric town. The game progresses on with the raven accumulating other various items from the townspeople which seem to satisfy his current materialistic desires and distracts him from his current nihilistic state. As Nietzsche would see it, the occupants in this town are "content" and "happy", in the sense that they are comfortable, secure, and tired of life, yet still nihilistic in an unorthodox way. All these ideals are representative of the Last Race, a society of status-quo loving bourgeois living repetitive and often tedious lives. When the raven finally acquires the spinning pinwheel in the "last" scene he realizes that the world is an eternal recurrence much like the pinwheel itself, reminding him of the inherently meaningless and repetitive life he is leading.

Like many people when faced with the idea that the world doesn't have an inherent meaning, the raven turns once again to a Schopenhauerian and nihilistic outlook as a coping mechanism to deal with this reality shattering idea. We can visually see his nihilistic worldview come back as the raven walks back to his house with the once colorful items he had collected and people he had seen before having been turned into bland, colorless rocks.

With the nihilistic and existentialist crisis at hand will the raven stay a Last Man seeking comfort and utilitarian values like his peers?

Or will he take a risk and struggle to become the Ubermensch in order to reaffirm his life in this eternally recurring universe?[/spoiler]

39273184.review: 这是一款没有“声音”的游戏，准确的来说，是一本没有对话的故事书。故事的主人公正是介绍中的诗歌里的Sir Raven。当你翻开这本故事书时，看到的是愁眉苦脸的Sir Raven对着笼子里的石头发愁。这时，门外的小女孩儿敲开了他的家门，给了她一束花。后来他开始了旅行，笼子里的东西逐渐变多，直到他来到了森林中……从这之后一切都变了，与Sir Raven交谈过的人都变成了石头，Sir Raven垂头丧气地将笼子里除了石头以外的东西一件一件放回到每个“人”身上，再一次回到家愁眉苦脸地对着笼子里的石头。整个故事值得玩家细细品味，背景音乐优美，画风很可爱。一个小小的提示，也许笼子里的不光是石头，而是”Heart“。BGM的歌词也有一些暗示哦。

39476587.review:
漆黑的乌鸦先生，轻快的音乐，清新的手绘画风。这是我对它的第一印象。
送花的姑娘，健硕的大叔，驼背却和蔼的婆婆，拿着蓝风车的荡着秋千的女孩。
粉色花瓣，翠色灌木，苍劲枝条，天蓝风车。与黑色的鸟笼。
幽远的晴空，平静的河面。红色的桥，和洁白的路面。
啊，真是美好呐。

到了结尾，已经不能前进。
那，就回去吧？
可是石块，石块，只剩下了石块。无色的石块。黑白色背景，空无一人的街巷。
他沮丧般地向回走着，脚步沉重又痛苦。
压抑使我的双手麻木。本来欢快的音乐，听起来那么忧伤。

求你们，回来。亦或者，回答我。

乌鸦先生侧着脸，我看不见他的表情。
他再次枯坐在桌子前，面前是笼子，和石块。




我不知道故事的主题是以什么为素材。按照乌鸦先生的穿着来看，应该是疫医。
但从贯穿全故事的鸟笼来看，我认为这是乌鸦先生的心。
他喜欢这里的每个人，他会对送花姑娘表达感谢，会和大叔打招呼，会礼貌的弯腰，向老人行礼。也会和小女孩一起玩风车。
啊，他爱生命里的这些美好。
但，如果占有了他们，那么，不就会更好吗？
如果他变得自私？那些人们会不会还对他温柔以待？
如果这是一场瘟疫？那些美好会不会永远存在于他的心底？
鸟笼里多了一块石块啊。
那是痛苦啊。
疫病带走他们对他的痛苦，会不会与他的孤独相当？
他是不会说话的，A raven that does not know how to croak.
乌鸦的声音是很刺耳的，不如说，是他选择了沉默？
我们选择去解释，然而唇边吐露出的却是伤人之语。
我们选择与死神下注，然而我们却输得一败涂地。

A Raven Monologue. 乌鸦独白
·A silent Raven
一只沉默的乌鸦。
·Fictional people
虚构的人物。
·Hand-drawn art
手绘艺术。
·A story that you can interpret without limit
一个你可以毫无限制地去解释的故事。
·Music by Christabel Annora
Christabel Annora制作的音乐。

仅仅只是一个无限可能的一种个人解读，涉及严重剧透。
乌鸦常与死亡相伴，是跨越死亡的存在。
乌鸦先生作为死亡的朋友，他一直不懂人类的灵魂。正巧少女的拜访，乌鸦先生看到灵魂的花朵。我可以取一点花儿吗，乌鸦先生说到。我想养出自己的花园。少女欣然接受。随后在街上碰到的男子的绿意，老人的小树，乌鸦先生都取了一些。最后在公园的小女孩，我只有这个风车可以给你了。
生死只在一瞬之间，小女孩全部的灵魂变为了石头，大家都以作古。一路返回的乌鸦先生，发现肉体已经消逝，但灵魂依在。可自己拿了来的灵魂却已化为磐石。他很苦恼，他不懂，是自己做错了什么吗？为什么自己永远不能理解呢。
乌鸦先生何时你才能知道，灵魂是在心中，而不是笼子里。
画风不错，音乐很美。就像看一个短片一样，有点说不上来的感觉。有空可以一试，最后感谢一下智哥的推荐，发现了这个游戏。

40949358.review:
[b] Just...let me wipe these tears [/b]

Despite how simple it may look, this holds a lot more than you might expect. This goes along as a regular storybook about a raven going out to socialize but soon goes deep into subverting expectations. Quickly going from a, “I’m viewing this cause I like how it looks and just want to see what happens” to “Okay...what is actually happening here”. This puts a high value on symbolism and letting the player interpret the meaning themselves. There really isn’t a wrong answer and anything anyone takes out of this is still right. 

I absolutely loved all the illustrations and especially the music that perfectly matches. While this might not be directly in the game, the poem that does with this is very great as well. And despite not having any dialogue, you can easily tell what is being talked about and how the characters feel.

This is a truly beautiful game and I’m really glad that I managed to find this. Like their previous title, this is a free experience that doesn’t take up a huge chunk of your time. Just try to not play this if you’re having a bad day, it very well may make you cry afterwards.

从一朵花开始。

我以为风筝消失之后一直退回到最初就可以原封不动地再见到那些人，结果只有石头。
所以这个游戏在讲故事的方式上很精妙的一点，就是你以为自己在控制游戏进度的进退，而实际上故事是单线推进的，那些人消失了，无论乌鸦先生在小镇的路途上往返多少次，也不过是越来越强化这个事实而已。中途一度停在某一个画面看先生垂着脑袋走啊走，经过了一棵大树三棵小树，又一棵大树三棵小树......他一直在那走，没有再遇到任何人，一首歌已经唱完了。

这让我想起原本在玩finding paradise时被触发的一些感受。相遇总是猝不及防的，而每一次告别时，我们总以为还能再次相见。当恍然发觉这种“以为”并不成立，我们如是定义“错过”。然后便派生出无数“我本应该”，“我原以为”，“我本可以”，以及“what if”的句式，比如，我本应该多看那个手捧花朵的姑娘两眼的。

“... and I dream of you.”

40750654.review:
Not a game to be played of course, but a beautiful visual story to see, without any dialogue at all.
The artwork and music is something truly unique to see, hear and enjoy,
and the fact that you can interpret the meaning behind this story without any possible limit or boundary makes it all the more interesting.

How i honestly interpreted the story was that [spoiler] the raven somewhat symbolises a basic introvert, who has clouded themselves in a monochromatic fantasy of how they believe the world turns. Though when they meet a new person (e.g the girl with the flowers), their confidence builds up as they leave their home to wander the town and meet others. And the items they are recieving symbolise the true meaning of all the people this raven meets, and the imrpovement in the raven's confidence and vision of the world around him. Though at the end, their confidence crumbles, with their monochromatic world returning, making them believe all these people, are fake, as to what the rocks may symbolise, and the sudden lack in colors in the town. And in the end, they return back to their home, back to square one in their monochromatic fantasy of a world. All of this could also somewhat tie into the lyrics of 'keep growing', where this raven grows and improves, but stumbles and falls back to square one in the end. [/spoiler]

Overall, if you are the type interested an intriguing short visual story that would only take up around five minutes of your time, this may be something of your personal interest.

40532314.review:
I love this a lot! It's beautiful, story-rich, and has great music. 

Personally, with the song entitled "Selfishness", and with the Raven taking, I interpret this as a story about giving and taking. When we progress to the right, we see the Raven taking from their speech bubbles, possibly implying that the Raven is taking more than what they're offering, or taking their ideas about the source of the material so the Raven could grow/make more on his own. Until the last girl who selflessly gives the Raven her pinwheel, the only thing she has (which is also the one thing given to the Raven that can't grow to be more and can't wilt). I think this is an act of her offering her friendship, or a part of herself, but the Raven only cares for items that benefit him.

Progressing to the left and looking back, the Raven doesn't at all remember the people, just what he gets from them. It's also possible that the Raven is asking for more, but the people don't have anything to give anymore. Having this materialistic view of only valuing what people can give him makes the Raven lonely. In the end, he opens the cage, and everything he has wilts, except for the rock which was the pinwheel. The rocks can mean that these are solid things that one should value - the generosity, or charity, or friendship of others, however, them being just 'rocks', could mean that they are unimportant to the Raven. 

Overall, I love it! Don't forget to say thanks for what's given to you!

40476234.review:
A Raven Monologue es un cuento ilustrado, con movimiento limitado, y una linda pero triste canción de fondo. El arte está muy bien logrado, con un estilo bien definido, de trazos limpios y colorido uniforme, en el que los gradientes son pasados por alto (a excepción del fondo del cielo) para darle un aspecto cercano a la de un libro ilustrado.

¿Qué es lo que nos cuenta? Supongo que está libre la interpretación y que cada quien puede tomar el mensaje como mejor le parezca. [spoiler]Acaso la generosidad de la gente, acaso el coleccionismo del cuervo o la tristeza de saber que todo lo material se pierde, dejándolo con una carga interior.[/spoiler]

Dura muy poco y nos deja con ganas de más. Si los chicos se animaran a crear más historias de estas, con una duración más larga, podrían venderse muy bien en Android y iOS, pero haciéndolas mucho más interactivas que simplemente pasar página.

¿Es recomendable? Bueno, por ser gratis, claro. Aunque lo he dicho ya, es muy corto y nos deja con ganas de más.

40206819.review:
http://steamcommunity.com/app/744810/discussions/0/1693785035812408081/


leaving this link at the top because it has a very interesting analysis on the narrative that i really enjoyed. 

i played this game after sleeping too much so i didn't quite get all of the narrative since my brain feels like mush, but i do agree that it seems to be about this one character (the raven) who deals with some sort of loss or fault. i interpretted it more as the raven has trouble connecting with people, at first the raven tries, and is mostly successful, but then at the end he ends up losing this one friend and soon that destroys all of his other relationships, though now that i think about it it doesn't really make sense. interpret the story how you want since there's no dialogue.

narrative aside, the art was abosolutely beautiful. the sketchy style with limited color palette really contributes to the gentleness of the delivery of the story, and the animations give even more life to the drawings. it truly feels like a digital picture book of some sort. 

however, i wish there was more interaction that contributes to the story besides hitting the arrow keys just to advance the story. i spent like half the time clicking on everything expecting some sort of meaningful interaction but was disappointed when i found none. at first i was expecting it to be more like a game but i realize now that i wouldn't call it a game even though it's interactive. i do like how towards the end the progression(?) reverses and gives a whole new meaning to the story. sorry if that doesn't make much sense, if you go through the monoluge you'll see what i mean.

overall i do highly recommend A Raven Monologue for the beautiful art and open story, plus it's free so it's not like you'll lose any money if you don't like it.

Um jogo curto, mas esplêndido em sua simplicidade.

A Raven Monologue não possui uma palavra e se limita a passar de uma cena/tela para outra - o que não desmerece em nada. A ambientação da trilha sonora se encaixa perfeitamente e ajuda na imersão do jogo, com certeza é um dos pontos fortes, juntamente com a arte e animação.

Muitas vezes achamos que precisamos dizer algo, e colocar tudo em palavras, para expressar como nos sentimos e o que queremos transmitir a alguém. Entretanto, o mais importante, e o que realmente importa em diversas ocasiões, são nossos gestos e nossas ações, independente de palavras. O jogo retrata bem isto, em minha interpretação.

Como dito, é extremamente curto, porém com uma mensagem linda! Vale a pena tirar alguns poucos minutinhos para apreciá-lo.

39921197.review:
'A Raven Monologue' is a very short art digital book from Surabaya, Indonesia developers who founded 'Mojiken Studio' back in 2013 http://mojikenstudio.com/ .Here they set out to challenge themselves to be able to tell a story with no verbal/written cues. Unfortunately they fail in my eyes, as both the haunting accompanying soundtrack by Christabel Annora  https://twitter.com/tabelnora and the accompanying poem on Store page, spell out prejudice details catering a gamer's interpretation somewhat. If they wanted to do an art piece with 'no' verbal cues then the accompanying soundtrack should have been solely instrumental, with its musical score telling you that there is something wrong, just like the 'family feud' failed tone does when it goes off. Neither should their have be an accompanying poem explaining what the three people visited by the raven are thinking. Noted, it's extremely difficult to tell a story without 'ANY' verbal or written notes, solely relying on artistic and instrumental rendering, but it is possible as shown by games like 'Kairo'.

Mojiken studio are no stranger to having challenges placed upon them. Because of losing personal image due to endless outsourcing, Mojiken decided to design their own Mojiken gaming boot camp which is an internal program to all of its staff members. The program aims to improve the skillset of its members by requesting them to meet various challenges so that they can learn gaming properly, and then share the results of those challenges to the public to generate unbiased feedback and constructive criticism. Challenges range from making a game using 'construct 2', too create a clone of a classic video game adding their own personal touch to it.

Mojiken is mainly made up of graphic artists, so a challenge definitely up their alley was to be able to produce a story relying simply on visuals. Somewhere during these laden challenges a need was identified in the collaboration field between indie musicians and game developers. This cross promotion, Good Samaritan image, let's help each other, was something that severely interested Mojiken and 'Raven monologue' was a by-product of that vision giving Mojiken a much needed, personal, driving force image to now be identified with. An indie gaming company, helping indie musicians, while sharing that journey with customers with the help of gaming boot camp.

The story is all about a silent raven unable to make noise visits three people taking/mimicking the voice bubble of three individuals in town by collecting and carrying it within a cage. Upon meeting a fourth individual in a park who does not speak, instead hands the raven a pinwheel. The pinwheel, and all people thus far met eventually turn into stone and the items collected in the cage vanish too leaving only a solitary rock in the cage. The rocks seem permanent as you can travel the same pathway again and collect the speech bubbles of the rocks, but there is no difference to the outcome. To witness all the visuals, all you have to do is scroll all the way to the right, back to the left and repeat the process. It will take you less than 5 minutes.

Gap artistry which requires you to fill in the gaps with your own experiences, isn't exactly a new concept, and while a benign underlying message from the developer might exist, open interpretation often prevents you from experiencing a profound connection to the developer and his or her hidden message, rather this type of gaming art reveals more about 'you' through your own chosen interpretation of events.

For instance, some interpret the story as a metaphor for social awkwardness, others think that its message is regarding to the fact that living things can't be controlled in cages. Some reflect a lesson on materialism, while others ponder a more sinister undertone and that the raven represents Death, ‘The Grim Reaper’, or a ‘Plague doctor’ in a ravaging Victorian era. 

Personally for me I reflect on the accompanying Store poem. The fact that the raven is addressed three times and that there are three speeches set inside the novel is more than a coincidence. If I set the three introductions and correspond them to the characters then I get the following...

(Victim 1: Little girl in quarantine looking forward to Death)

Dearest Sir Raven,
Do you still wander around without end?
Crafting colours under the still and silent
Not knowing I'm waiting here alone without a friend

(Victim 2: An obese person looking forward to death because of experiencing severe health problems and not being able to do what they use to)

Dearest Sir Raven,
When you are around, would you mind to stop by?
Just a hello, just a moment
To let me savour the memories before our goodbye

(Victim 3: An older person at the end of their tether looking forward to death due to their belief in an afterlife reward)

Dearest Sir Raven,
Let us go home
To the place devoid of reality frame
Where I shall watch over us even without a logical form

(Victim 4 is a girl who does not know she is about to die).

Regardless of their thoughts and memories of their being. Death is permeant that being its sound.

Offcourse this is my own personal interpretation and whether I’ve hit the nail on the head precisely to the point that the developers are convinced that I’m a mind reader and they are now considering going to work wearing tin foil hats, only time will tell.

The artwork itself is rather 2D and trivial, it’s actually the afterthought discussion from the thought provoking, the observational and keen decipher, the witty and resourceful comedian and even the selfish, hard hearted, refuse to look any further remarks from a self-centred gamer which makes this experience one worthy of ravening about.

Full novel below...

https://youtu.be/0nB3mTHqz8g

Es corto, sí, pero lo vale. El estilo del dibujo es maravilloso y que cada panel esté hecho a mano lo hace aun mejor, debo decir, el esfuerzo que le pusieron a valido la pena. La selección de colores está en un balance tal que, ni es pálido, ni está tan saturado como para cansar la vista, ni está sobrecargado de color, es una obra hecha para el deleite del ojo. Lo visual más la música de fondo hacen que al verlo se experiencie un momento de paz, o al menos a mí me ha relajado mucho verlo.

Con respecto a la historia, sí, es para interpretarla cada uno a su manera. Para mí, "aprovecha el hoy, agradece lo que tienes,  intenta ser la mejor versión de ti mismo, y no gastes tu tiempo en conflictos, no lo valen. Cuando uno menos se lo espera, el tiempo pasa, y nunca sabrás si perderas aquellas cosas que aprecias o de las que no tenias consciente que apreciabas tanto".

39915981.review: Ah yes, A Raven Monologue. What is there to say about this game? Nothing. As no one in the game says anything either. Well that's unfair to say so I'll summarize the story. This is a game about a plague doctor who likes to trade, so he goes around town with his magical bird cage of wonders and grants them anything they want. He collects all the resources he could want. But then the bird man sees a little girl with a pinwheel, bird man WANTS the pinwheel, so he offers a trade, but instead of trading the little girl offers it for free, because they are a little angle. Birdman stares into the pinwheel because I guess thats how birdman roles. Little did he know the fucker laced the pinwheel with god knows what, awe in bird man's hobble back to his house with his mind in the gutter. Witness the wonders of drugs and see what it does. Poor birdman can only see rocks, what did he do to deserve it? Once at his house bird man ponders if his name does indeed have a space or if it's one word. He also wonders if clicking on anything does shit. Anyways, birdman's mind actually gets obliterated as no matter what people are now rocks and he will never be the same until you let him rest by exiting the game. Great game but if we are being serious here, is their a space in brid-man's name? Or does birdman have a hyphin? The mysteries of bird man will never be unvailled. Unless the fan pack has something to answer, but I don't feel like coughing up money so maybe I'll see some other day.

39858716.review:
Como diz a descrição do jogo, ele não é propriamente um jogo, e sim, uma curta e silenciosa história ficcional sobre um corvo que não sabe crocitar e seu relacionamento com as pessoas da cidade. O uso de setas indicativas são a única interação permitida com a história, porém o apurado desenho artísitco, o roteiro bem construído e a música magnífica submergem você na mesma. 
Mesmo sem nenhuma explícita referência a mitologia nórdica, é impossível não perceber que A Raven Monologue trabalha com os arquétipos dos corvos de Odin, Hugin (pensamento) e Munin (memória) e ainda faz  referência ao poema The Raven (O Corvo) de Edgar Alan Poe. 
Uma obra prima gratuita na STEAM. Altamente recomendada.

39856107.review:
As most reviews and the game itself says, it's more of an interactive story than a real "graphics and interface" game. 

A very sweet story that invokes a lot of thought and emotion on what the meaning could really be. I'll leave you to figure it out for yourself, since the interpretation is really up to a personal thought process. 

Great music and animation with a very interesting style. The story-telling method is really one that can only be donein  this form of media due to the inverse chronological nature and use of color. Really fascinating use of the materials they had. A superb job overall that I recommend greatly!

tldr; short play time with great music and art! interesting story that brings out a lot of thought!

39839023.review:
怎么说呢，个人认为音乐和画风不错。但也仅此而已了吧。
或许是期望过高的原因，玩完一遍后反而有些失望，试着多玩了几次，感触也没有变深。
先说被很多评测夸赞的故事，这故事实在是过于浅显易懂、题材也不新鲜，也没有用什么特别的讲述方式，整体都没什么新意。只有一首歌不停轮放，虽然说对于这游戏是足够的，不过这反而也能看得出来这流程是有多短多无趣...连最基本的渲染气氛也做的不是那么好。要说同一主题的话我觉得比这个更好的作品有许多，无论是游戏范围里还是小说范围里。
交互模式上，只有左右键很单调。一开始看着完全戳中我内心的画风，满心以为是能点击画面的，结果点来点去能点的只有下面的左右键...虽然说最后的倒退让我眼前一亮，但光靠这一点实在是不够啊。如果有什么隐藏的剧情或者互动就好了，希望是我还没玩透吧，因为我非常喜欢这简简单单的叙事方式和画风，但是这音乐太洗脑了，这种游戏玩了太多遍反而让印象越来越差...可以形容为卖相很好、第一口让人惊讶的甜品，只是吃了好几个就会腻味吧。
看到有个差评，说这根本不是游戏。唔、我个人想法是不要太纠结在这一点上，虽然我是同意这个说法的。不过我还是觉得这款游戏值得推荐，总的来讲，第一印象还是很让人惊讶又动心的。不过毕竟不是小说，也没什么更深度的意味，一两遍就够了。
不过我最差评的其实是必须要回到最初的界面才能关掉游戏的这点，对我这种不喜欢用任务管理器的人很恶意啊。

39838612.review:
這是一個關於孤獨的故事。

它不能算是一個「遊戲」，卻是一部優秀的繪本。

畫面一開始是一隻烏鴉先生坐在椅子上，對著一個籠子，裡面有一塊石頭。
故事開始播放後，烏鴉先生分別遇到了穿粉衣服的少女、赤腳的男子、拄拐杖的老奶奶、藍衣服的女孩。
這些人都很友善，各給烏鴉先生一件禮物：鮮花、綠葉、樹枝、風車。至於這些東西是否象徵什麼？玩家可以自行想像，
對我來說這些東西象徵生命的美好。
而且整體畫面的顏色種類不多，大多以黑、白、灰為主，因此當畫面出現「顏色」，都是經過精心安排，強化我們閱讀時的情感變化。

一路上我們看不見烏鴉先生的表情，然後在故事轉折的時候，出現一張是烏鴉先生正面的畫面............
逐漸打破前面觀賞時的和諧氣氛。


這部繪本巧妙的設計在於，可以順著看，也可以逆著看。兩種角度讀出兩種心情況味。
「烏鴉先生」就像是一部無言的寓言，象徵我們人類生活在社會群體中必定會面對的情境，
孤獨、寂寞、空虛、悲哀，只是每個人的感受、程度不同而已，但都是人生中必經的旅程。

美好的東西終會消逝，時間不可挽回，時間的推移必定帶來人生之悲哀。

不過儘管它傳遞了一個生命共有的情感主題，我不認為這是一個極為悲哀的作品，相反的，以白、黑為主的色彩架構，整體色調的柔和、明亮，讓觀賞者能有一個舒適、愉悅的心情，也許人生真的有很多陰鬱、悲傷等負面情緒的時候，但當你收到一朵鮮花、一支漂亮的風車，一份簡單、質樸的善意，讓你覺得這世界還是值得你活著看看這些美好。


如果孤獨是人生必免不了的課題，不如學會與孤獨相處、享受孤獨。

真好。想和制作组谈一场冬天的恋爱。
春天到了就会结束，也没关系。

不要和人类接触，因为他们太脆弱，太短暂。
但是。
这样的故事里总是有一个但是。
最初的时候，那段时光真的非常美好。想带给你的礼物，遇见的人，走过的街道。
那些人不在了以后，Raven又在这个小镇里呆了多久呢。
把石头堆在他们曾在的地方，和他们说话，走很远的路去见想见的人，带着给你的礼物。
风车、花、草都太短暂了。
人也是。
但是。
Raven还想在这里再待一会儿。
就算风车、花、草都不在了。
Raven还是打算再待一会儿。
他是那块鸟笼里的石头，他把自己放进了笼子里。
而他愿意。
他放进笼子里的花和草很快就不见了。
他想见的人也不见了。他把自己和花和草一起提着，走很长很长的路，想去见的那个人，也不见了。
但是他还想再待一会儿。
没关系。

Some things are worth getting your heart broken for.

[h1]"Короткая и грустная мини-история."[/h1]

Данный пятиминутный проект [strike]рассказывает[/strike] показывает нам историю о некоем "вороне", и о его взаимоотношениях с жителями красивого городка.

[h1]НЮАНСЫ:[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Очень симпатичные и приятные глазу иллюстрации.
    [*]Милая меллодия, сопровождающая нас всю "игру".
    [*]После [strike]прохождения[/strike] просмотра появляется желание обдумать увиденное, что немаловажно.
    [*]Есть дополнительный контент.
[/list]

[h1]ИТОГ:[/h1]
Очень ламповая игра, которая дает возможность просто ненадолго расслабиться.

[h1]Written by Aqwat.[/h1]

39645653.review:
Both free and short, there's no reason to miss out on this one. 

The art style is beautiful and works really well with the music; the choice of using a book-like storyline is really interesting and having to go back to see the whole pic is a really smart move. 

The story itself is kinda sad if you try over analyzing it. The music fits well the atmosphere and helps giving the emotion necessary to feel empathy for the protagonist; the use of colors to show the Raven's emotions as they meet people is really well thought and fits the whole theme.

Simple and beautiful, this game deserves a 10/10.

39643113.review: This game probably isnt for everyone, but if you like art, if you like feeling, if you like being a human, and know what being human can be, you will love this game. You can relate to this simple little game and love it the entire time. Download this game and I promise you wont regret it. Your heartstrings will love you for it.
